page.title: 08NEWTOWN CHURCH
page.content: Newtown church was built in 1849 of flint and stone with pointed lancet windows designed by John Colson and cost Â£1,500, paid by William Garnier of Rookesbury Park, Wickham, who also contributed Â£1,300 to the vicarage which was built in 1852. It remained a separate parish until it was united with Soberton in 1953. Dedicated to St.Paul originally, but changed to the Holy Trinity in 1880. Contains seats for 120 people in an ecclesiastical parish of 800. Contrary to current trends, numbers attending family communion have risen over the last few decades, averaging 40-50 each Sunday. There is a two-manual organ, tonally well-suited to the accoustics of the building and a choir of 28, comprising of 12 adults & 16 children. In a 4 week month, a total of ll services are held in the church.
